p.s: Following I am going to analyze the dialogue between Walter and Ruth, considering their dreams compared to the ones of the other family members.
From the beginning it is very clear that Ruth and Walter do not listen to each other.

Considering that Walter ignores her wife (l. 3) and Ruth states that she already know what his husband was thinking about in the bathroom (cf. l. 2) it becomes clear that they are both tired of each other and their different interests.
And so does Walter explainsexplain in lines 11 to 14.
You get to know that Ruth is tired of everything.
About the family and the living conditions.
He calls their home a beat-up hole which is a sign that he alsalso do not like their way of life either.
Though he has different dreams compared to his family members.
He wants to open a liquor store because he is annoyed of his work with the white people and wants to become independantindependent.
Also Beneatha has got more future considering dreams.
She wants to become a doctor and therefore needs the money for her education.
But she also says that the money belongs to Mama and it is up to her what is done with it.
Though that does not stop her fighting for her dream.
The rest of the family members want to invest in a house with better living conditions, so that they have more windows, their own rooms and a garden for Mama and Travis.

So you can see that Walter's dream is in great contrast to the other dreams and that is why he feels lonely, insecured and also betrayed especially from his mom and his wife, as she asks Ruth: You couldn't be on my side that long, for nothing could you (ll. 13-14).
And also he thinks that Mama listeneslistens to Ruth more than to him (cf. l. 18f.).
In addition it seems that Walter only focuses on his own dreams.
He doesn't considersconsider the other family members in his actions since he needs all the ten thousand dollars for his investment in the liquor store (cf. l. 28).
Furthermore he does not care about his wife a lot.
He explains: A man needs for a woman to back him up... (l. 16) although Ruth asks him to leave her alone.
This shows that Walter is not interested in his wife's interests but his own.
But also from Ruth's side there is no much acception as she doesn't look up at him when Walter speaks and doesn't answer to his questions (l. 12).
All in all you can say that there is a conflict between them and their marriage of eleven years.
They both do not listen to each other's problems or interests.
That is the reason why they feel betrayed.
You can add that there seems no solution in sight.
In the beginning of the dialogue Ruth, at least considers what Walter tells her but in the end she just says: Walter, leave me alone!Eat your eggs, the gonna be cold (l. 34).

Walter seems annoyed about her behaviour and makes fun of her statement while exaggerating it with his immaginatedimaginated dialogue: Man say: I got to change my life, I'm choking to death, baby! And his woman say: [...] Your eggs is getting cold! (ll. 37-38).
Another striking aspect is the fact that Ruth tells him after this exaggeration that it wasn't none of his money (cf. l. 39).
He replaces the word business which is normally used in this case, with the word money which clarifies how important money has become to Walter but also the other family members.
Money plays the central role through the whole play.
And even if some family members like Mama or Beneatha do not consider it as that important they all talk about it a lot because it is essential for realizing their dreams.
Although Walter seems to just focus on his own dreams, he also cares about his family at least his son Travis.
In the end he says very, very quietly that all [he] got to give [his son] is stories about how rich white people live (l. 42f.).
Through this sentence you can see that Walter does care about his family and he does want better living conditions too, but he wants to realize it with an investment in a liquor store.
But he also does not seem to listen to the advices of her family and his wife Ruth, who considerconsiders the liquor store as a bad idea (cf. l. 4, l. 26, l. 31).
Concluding you can say, that Walter is not so sure about what he wants yet.

He may seem at first sight because he plans and justifies his dream of having a liquor store but after analyzing this extract of the scene it is clear that Walter Lee is just in process of finding himself.
He is questioning about his human being as he searches support from his wife and the other family members.
The bathroom (cf. l. 1) and the mirror (cf. l. 40) can be seen as a symbol of his search for identity.
